occurrences.line_text: To burne the same with vnquenchable fire,
But nothing new to him was that same paine,
For that same Brute, whom much he did aduaunce
Faire Britomart and that same Faerie knight
Yet sith he n'ote saue both, he sau'd that same,
Well weened he, that those the same mote bee,
The same behold, therewith their keene desires were whet.
Into the same he creepes, and thenceforth there
So mighty be th'enchauntments, which the same do stay.
How ouer that same dore was likewise writ,
Or that same daintie lad, which was so deare
As those same plumes, so seemd he vaine and light,
That his proud spoyle of that same dolorous
For thy, from that same roome not to depart
When that same Maske againe should forth arize.
Saue that same woefull Ladie, both whose hands
Which wrought it, could the same recure againe.
Hearing him those same bloudy lines reherse;
Was vanisht quite, as it were not the same,
At this same furrowes end, till a new day:
For fault of few that haue abusd the same.
For that same vile Enchauntour Busyran,
The very selfe same day that she was wedded,
But that same younker soone was ouer throwne,
That none the same may easily out win;
And those same cursed seedes doe also serue
That did those armes and that same scutchion weld,
Will chalenge yond same other for my fee:
I saw, why should I doubt to tell the same?
Which that same witch had in this forme engraft,
Returned readie newes, that those same weare
Which Clotho graunting, shewed her the same:
Vpon which ground this same great battell grew,
And pledges pawnd the same to keepe a right,
It left; but that same soule, which therein dwelt,
That from the same the fierie sparkles flasht,
He heav'd on high, in mind with that same blow
That in the same she farre exceld all other.
Is this, then that same water of Ardenne,
It was the same, which lately Florimel had lost.
That same aloft he hong in open vew,
But him likewise with that same speare he eke did quell.
The shield and armes well knowne to be the same,
The instrument of wrath, and with the same
Which Cambell seeing, much the same enuyde,
Might not the same about her middle weare.
The same one day, when she her selfe disposd
No wonder then, if that to winne the same
About their tender loynes to knit the same;
He gan to cast how to appease the same,
For aye the more that she the same reherst,
For time yet serues that I the same refuse,
Which that same knight, whom by his launce I read,
To be the same, for whom they did abyde.
And round about the same, her yellow heare
To be the same which in her fathers hall
Hath linckt with me in the same chaine attone?
And that same gentle Squire arriu'd in place,
Where this same cursed caytiue did appeare,
For naught the same may calme ne mitigate,
So sensibly compyld, that in the same
The same he tooke, and with a riband new,
And washt the same with water, which did well
Of that same wicked Carle, by Virgins hond;
He all the way did rage at that same Squire,
Who as he gan the same to him aread,
But that same dwarfe right sorie seem'd and sad,
But suffred that same Dwarfe me to her dongeon driue.
And that same Squire of treason to vpbraide.
Then tooke he that same Dwarfe, and him compeld
Then gan they ransacke that same Castle strong,
And that same bitter corsiue, which did eat
Whose like they neuer saw till that same houre:
Was for the loue of that same snowy maid,
Till Scudamour, and that same Briton maide,
And told at large how that same errant Knight,
That this same braue emprize for me did rest,
Or that in Cyprus, both long since this same,
Till at the last I spide within the same,
The same to all stoode alwaies open wide:
Not that same famous Temple of Diane,
Was hard to know, for that her Priests the same
And dayly yet thou doest the same repayre:
But thou the same for pleasure didst prepayre.
That same was fayrest Amoret in place,
But that same Ladie which me friended late
Of warlike Amazons, which doe possesse the same.
Locrinus them aueng'd, and the same date,
For in the selfe same riuer, where he late
Yet all those same were there, which erst I did recount.
That that same former fatall wound of his
Now lesse she feared that same fatall read,
For that same golden fleecy Ram, which bore
Ne is that same great glorious lampe of light,
Well prou'd in that same day, when Ioue those Gyants quelled.
Tempred with Adamant amongst the same,
If I should graunt that I haue doen the same,
In that same place, whereas it now doth lie.
Expressing well his nature, which the same did wield.
By that same carefull Squire did then abide,
Beare for his penaunce that same Ladies head;
But that same Squire, to whom she was more dere,
As that ye would for little leaue the same,
And in the same are many trap fals pight,
And vnderneath the same a riuer flowes,
If ought he had the same to counterpoys.
He would to his owne part restore the same againe.
And counterpeise the same with so much wrong.
With th'other drew his sword: for with the same
Throughout the hall, for that same warlike horse.
As that same other Isle, that greater bredth now beares.
Loue that same other Damzell, Lucy bright,
But this same other Damzell since hath fained,
And that she did transport the same by sea,
But that same wretched man, ordaynd to die,
And made the scorne of Knighthod this same day.
I shortly will to you rehearse the same,
Where that same Damzell lowdly him bespake,
In sort as ye haue heard the same of late.
Then this same vertue, that doth right define:
Such is the powre of that same fruit, that nought
I will not seeke the same from you to hide,
They doe to thee in this same dreame discouer.
For that same Crocodile doth represent
For that same Crocodile Osyris is,
To craue the same, whom errour so misled,
Nor vndertake the same, for cowheard feare,
And that same citie, so now ruinate,
To sperre the gate; but that same lumpe of clay,
And asked him, if that he were the same,
That same is it, which fought for you this day.
Wayting what end would be of that same daunger drad.
The same longwhile I bore, and therewithall
And that same yron man which could reueale
To blot the same with blame, or wrest in wicked sort.
But this same both her selfe, and others eke perplext.
He this same day, as I that way did come
To punish those, that doe deserue the same;
Yet no whit more appalled for the same,
Well weend he streight, that he should be the same,
Of that same Ladie, whether what he spoke,
Through that same perillous foord with better heede,
And let thy Lady likewise doe the same.
And all the while, that same discourteous Knight,
Looking at that same Carle with count'nance grim,
Finde fauour to be lodged there for that same night.
Toward the same incessantly did ronne,
And held the same so hard, that by no wize
But that same Ladies hurts no herbe he found,
To leape into the same after our liues end.
That now the same he greatly doth forthinke.
She gladly did of that same babe accept,
As ye may know, when time shall be to tell the same.
Of that same Monster late, for lacke of heed,
For want of taking heede vnto the same,
And eke could doe, as well as say the same,
For that same beast was bred of hellish strene,
And that same Knight and Saluage standing by,
He saw the ground all strow'd, and that same Knight
He well remembred, that the same was hee,
Effect the same, whylest all the night was spent.
But that same knight would not once let him start,
But that same foole, which most increast her paines,
Be well aware, how ye the same doe vse,
The selfe same euening fortune hether droue,
In that same quest which Fortune on him cast,
Therein well practisd was, and in the same
And in the middest of those same three, was placed
Vpon her yuory forehead that same day
So taking leaue of that same gentle swaine,
By some of these same theeues at the instant brunt,
And therefore prayd, that those same captiues there
For that same mayd, how euer it him greeues,
Fayre Pastorell, who with the selfe same wound
In that same conflict (woe is me) befell
The selfe same flocks, the which those theeues had reft
Was that same infant, which so long sith past
The same againe if now ye list to haue,
The same is yonder Lady, whom high God did saue.
That yond same is your daughter sure, which yet doth liue.
Free Samient from feare:
So said this Damzell, that hight Samient,
And then that Damzell, the sad Samient,
In silken samite she was light arayd,
Mortall Samnitis, and Cicuta bad,
She was as safe as in a Sanctuary;
And soone arriued on the shallow sand,
The whiles his nets were drying on the sand:
For it did glister like the golden sand,
His sandales were with toilesome trauell torne,
For on a sandie hill, that still did flit,
And lying downe vpon the sandie graile,
Such as Diana by the sandie shore
Till sadly soucing on the sandie shore,
Through boyling sands of Arabie and Ynde;
From shore to shore, emongst the Lybicke sands,
And Dart, nigh chockt with sands of tinny mines.
To tell the sands, or count the starres on hye,
Either by being wreckt vppon the sands,
His sandy lockes, long hanging downe behind,
That th'vtmost sandy breach they shortly fetch,
On the rough rocks, or on the sandy shallowes,
And Xanthus sandy bankes with bloud all ouerflowne.
The sandy Slane, the stony Aubrian,
That all his bones, as small as sandy grayle
By Sanglamort my sword, whose deadly dent
He doeth auenge on Sanglier
Sir Sanglier; (so cleeped was that Knight)
That was to weet, the stout Sir Sangliere,
Well pleased with that doome was Sangliere,
But Sangliere disdained much his doome,
And into a deepe sanguine dide the grassie ground.
That like a liuely sanguine it seem'd to the eye.
That dyde in sanguine red her skin all snowy cleene.
Sans foy: full large of limbe and euery ioint
Who whiles he liu'de, was called proud Sans foy,
Of one bad sire, whose youngest is Sans ioy,
And twixt them both was borne the bloudy bold Sans loy.
And on his shield Sans loy in bloudie lines was dyde.
Was writ Sans ioy, they new arriued find:
Who when the shamed shield of slaine Sans foy
Euen stout Sans foy (O who can then refrayn?)
Ah deare Sans ioy, next dearest to Sans foy,
Ah deare Sans ioy, next dearest to Sans foy,
Saluagesse sans finesse, shewing secret wit.
Of him, that slew Sansfoy with bloudie knife;
Life from Sansfoy thou tookst, Sansloy shall fro[m] thee take.
Of deare Sansfoy, I neuer ioyed howre,
For that I would not yeeld, that to Sans-foy I gaue.
Dead is Sans-foy, his vitall paines are past,
Sans-foy his shield is hangd with bloudy hew:
The bold Sansfoy shrinke vnderneath his speare;
And he the man that made Sansfoy to fall,
And with Sans-foyes dead dowry you endew.
Where brothers death to wreak Sansioy
Lo where the stout Sansioy doth sleepe in deadly shade.
The combat, which he with Sansioy did hould;
Life from Sansfoy thou tookst, Sansloy shall fro[m] thee take.
Till her vnwares the fierce Sansloy did ouertake.
But he that lou'd the youngest, was Sans-loy,
Fast by her side did sit the bold Sans-loy
Soft Spio, sweete Eudore, Sao sad,
Which feedes each liuing plant with liquid sap,
That from one roote deriu'd their vitall sap:
Like an old Oke whose pith and sap is seare,
Here by the Gods, and fed with heauenly sap,
Whose sappy liquor, that with fulnesse sweld,
A faithlesse Sarazin all arm'd to point,
The Sarazin sore daunted with the buffe
Curse on that Crosse (quoth then the Sarazin)
At last it chaunced this proud Sarazin
Soone after comes the cruell Sarazin,
The Sarazin was stout, and wondrous strong,
Whom when the raging Sarazin espide,
The Sarazin this hearing, rose amain,
Whom all so soone as that proud Sarazin
And Briton fields with Sarazin bloud bedyde,
At last when as the Sarazin perceiu'd,
A cursed cruell Sarazin doth wonne,
The Sarazin, awayting for some spoile.
The Sarazins shield, signe of the conqueroure.
From Turkes and Sarazins, which them had stayd;
And those two Sarazins confounded late,
To banish feare, and with Sardonian smyle
And thousand Sar'zins foully donne to dye.
And heauie sat vpon her palfrey slow:
Vnder them neuer sat, ne wont there sound
Teaching the Satyres, which her sat around,
Sat downe to rest in middest of the race:
Yet still he sat, and inly did him selfe torment.
And fast beside him sat tumultuous Strife:
Before the dore sat selfe-consuming Care,
And thereon sat a woman gorgeous gay,
Twise sixteen warders sat, all armed bright
Some plaid with strawes, some idly sat at ease;
Supper was shortly dight and downe they sat,
And eke the gentle shepheard swaynes, which sat
And his embrodered Bonet sat awry;
And when he sate vpon his courser free,
Sate in eternall night: nought could she say,
On which there sate most braue embellished
Ere long she fownd, whereas he wearie sate,
And by her side there sate a gentle paire
And one sate wayting euer them before,
That still he sate long time astonished
Where sate a gentle Lady all alone,
By which there sate a knight with helme vnlast,
The goddesse heard, and suddeine where she sate,
Betwixt them both the faire Medina sate
Vpon her eyelids many Graces sate,
And therein sate a Ladie fresh and faire,
By that wayes side, there sate infernall Payne,
On thother side in one consort there sate,
Beside his head there sate a faire young man,
Now bene they come, whereas the Palmer sate,
Within the Barbican a Porter sate,
At th'upper end there sate, yclad in red
A louely beuy of faire Ladies sate,
Emongst them all sate he, which wonned there,
When oblique Saturne sate in the house of agonyes.
There sate a man of ripe and perfect age,
And therein sate an old old man, halfe blind,
Which still sate waiting on that wastfull clift,
Which thither came: but in the Porch there sate
For death sate on the point of that enchaunted speare.
Sate downe vpon the dusty ground anon,
They sate to meat, and Satyrane his chaunce
But he him selfe sate looking still askaunce,
And her before the vile Enchaunter sate,
As she sate carelesse by a cristall flood,
She them saluting, there by them sate still,
And therein sate a Ladie passing faire
We did alight, and sate in shadow myld;
Vpon a day as she him sate beside,
And eke the Doue sate by the Faulcons side,
On th'one side he, on th'other sate Delay,
But therein sate an amiable Dame,
And next to her sate goodly Shamefastnesse,
And next to her sate sober Modestie,
And her against sate comely Curtesie,
Thus sate they all a round in seemely rate:
Euen in the lap of VVomanhood there sate,
Iustice sate high ador'd with solemne feasts,
This day as I in solace sate hereby
But right sate in the middest of the beame alone.
That sate thereby, with gyantlike resemblance,
Who sate on high, that she might all men see,
Encompassed the throne, on which she sate:
And round about, before her feet there sate
Sate goodly Temperance in garments clene,
Whylest vnderneath her feete, there as she sate,
Sate with a knight in ioyous iolliment
And there beside him sate vpon the ground
So downe he sate, and with delightfull pleasure
The lustie shepheard swaynes sate in a rout,
And sate there still, vntill the flying day
Whether it were to caroll, as they sate
Rode Sathan, with a smarting whip in hand,
And pleasd them all with meete satietie,
When all men had with full satietie
Hauing all satisfide their bloudy thurst,
Not all so satisfide, with greedie eye
And their importune fates all satisfide:
Not satisfide so farre her to estraunge
Yet note their hungry vew be satisfide,
Nathlesse she rested not so satisfide,
But floods of bloud could not them satisfie:
Why should not that dead carrion satisfie
Ne seeing could her wonder satisfie,
Did greatly wonder, ne could satisfie
He glad to satisfie, him selfe prepar'd
If that (said Guyon) may you satisfie,
Ne could with seeing satisfie his great desire.
Or what doth his bad death now satisfy
Not satisfyde till on the fatall ground
Who nathelesse not therewith satisfyde,
For else his feare could not be satisfyde.
With small adoe, and nature satisfyde,
Her lothsome pleasure there to satisfye;
And quilted vppon sattin white as milke,
When oblique Saturne sate in the house of agonyes.
Next Saturne was, (but who would euer weene,
That sullein Saturne euer weend to loue?
And next to him old Saturne, that was wont be best.
For during Saturnes ancient raigne it's sayd,
Yet loue is sullein, and Saturnlike seene,
But if that thou, Sir Satyran, didst weete,
That Satyran a girdle did vptake,
He pricked forth in ayd of Satyran;
Tho vnto Satyran she was adiudged,
Thereat exceeding wroth was Satyran;
And wroth with Satyran was Blandamour;
Ah Satyrane, my dearling, and my ioy,
To Satyrane she shewed her intent:
Where is (said Satyrane) that Paynims sonne,
Faire Vna: whom when Satyrane espide,
But Satyrane with strokes him turning, staid,
Whilest Satyrane him from pursuit did let:
Satyrane saues the Squire of Dames
It was to weete the good Sir Satyrane,
Which whenas Satyrane beheld, in hast
By this the good Sir Satyrane gan wake
Her well beseemes that Quest (quoth Satyrane)
(Thereat full hartely laughed Satyrane.)
Perdy, (said Satyrane) thou Squire of Dames,
To tell of Satyrane, where I him left of late.
Sir Satyrane him towards did addresse,
Ah gentle knight (said then Sir Satyrane)
Ne long shall Satyrane behind you stay,
The cause, why Satyrane and Paridell
Thereat Sir Satyrane gan smile, and say;
Nay let vs first (said Satyrane[)] entreat
But Satyrane forth stepping, did them stay
They sate to meat, and Satyrane his chaunce
Sir Satyrane, that glaunces might not glyde:
Who with Sir Satyrane, as earst ye red,
Ne was Sir Satyrane her far behinde,
It was not Satyrane, whom he did feare,
Satyrane makes a Turneyment
Then first of all forth came Sir Satyrane,
Then tooke the bold Sir Satyrane in hand
And now by this, Sir Satyrane abraid,
So Satyrane that day was iudg'd to beare the bell.
And with the first the hardy Satyrane
There Satyrane Lord of the field he found,
It chaunst Sir Satyrane his steed at last,
To rescue Satyrane out of his pray;
But Satyrane boue all the other crew,
Thus was Sir Satyrane with all his band
That Satyrane the first day best had donne:
To single combat with Sir Satyrane.
Which troublous stirre when Satyrane auiz'd:
A Satyre chaunst her wandring for to find,
But euery Satyre first did giue a busse
Embraced of a Satyre rough and rude,
And would haue wakt the Satyre by her syde;
A troupe of Faunes and Satyres far away
But all the Satyres scorne their woody kind,
A Satyres sonne yborne in forrest wyld,
Teaching the Satyres, which her sat around,
So on a day when Satyres all were gone,
Too late it was, to Satyres to be told,
And in his Scutchin bore a Satyres hed:
Findes emongst Satyres, whence with him
Till on a day the Satyres her espide
The iolly Satyres full of fresh delight,
That none of all the Satyres him espyde or heard.
But chose emongst the iolly Satyres still to wonne.
In Satyres shape Antiopa he snatcht:
Which oft the Paynim sau'd from deadly stowre.
Who wrongd by Carle by Proteus sau'd,
Gathred the Troian reliques sau'd from flame,
Yet sith he n'ote saue both, he sau'd that same,
For that he sau'd the victour from fordonne:
Thine honor sau'd, though into thraldome throwne?
Which this dayes honour sau'd to Marinell;
And sau'd from being to that caitiue thrall.
Till she had sau'd so many loues, as she did lose.
Yet sau'd not so, but that the bloud it drew,
Till I haue sau'd so many, as I earst did slay.
To marchants, but was sau'd with strong defence?
Her selfe a yeelded pray to saue or spill.
A worke of wondrous grace, and able soules to saue.
That Mercy in the end his righteous soule might saue.
They might appeare, when he their soules shall saue.
And shewes the way, his sinfull soule to saue.
To saue his bodie from the scorching fire,
Saue in that soile, where all good things did grow,
Into that same he fell: which did from death him saue.
Does ride on both their backs, & faire her selfe doth saue.
Not caring how, her silly life to saue,
And both from rocks and flats it selfe could wisely saue.
The other both from drowning for to saue,
To saue my Lord, in wretched plight forlore;
Eternall God thee saue from such decay.
Saue as thou seest or hearst. But well I wote,
That no enchauntment from his dint might saue;
But him henceforth the same can saue no more;
Fly fast, and saue your selues from neare decay,
And many good knights slaine, that haue vs sought to saue.
Learning his ship from those white rocks to saue,
But being all defeated, saue a few,
Ne ought saue perill, still as he did pas:
And the rich wares to saue from pitteous spoyle,
Saue in this Paradise, be heard elswhere:
Ne ought their goodly workmanship might saue
Saue Beares, Lions, & Buls, which romed them around.
Madnesse to saue a part, and lose the whole.
Saue to the noble knight Sir Scudamore,
Nor halfe so fast to saue her maidenhed,
Bad her commaund my life to saue, or spill.
And her to saue from outrage, meekely prayed him.
To saue her honor from that villaine vild,
To saue her selfe from that outrageous spoyle,
Saue one old Nymph, hight Panope to keepe it cleane.
To saue his people sad from victours vengefull hands.
Saue an huge nation of the Geaunts broode,
Yet sith he n'ote saue both, he sau'd that same,
To saue his life, ne let him be descryde,
Saue that same woefull Ladie, both whose hands
Be sure, that nought may saue thee from to dy,
She sought to saue, as thing reseru'd from stealth;
So could she forge all colours, saue the trew.
And saue her honour with your ventrous paines;
That chaleng'd ought in Florimell, saue they alone.
He forced was to strike, and saue him selfe from teene.
Him selfe to saue, and daunger to defend,
Him selfe to saue from that so deadly throw;
Ne either cared life to saue or spill,
To let him loose, to saue their proper stakes;
Saue that she algates him a while accompanide.
That forst him flie abacke, himselfe to saue:
And sailers saue from wreckes of wrathfull winde.
So shall you by one gift saue all vs three aliue.
Her to haue swallow'd vp, did helpe to saue her.
To saue her from her feare, and him from force to let.
Oft spilles the principall, to saue the part;
That seekes to saue the subiect of her skill,
As it is greater prayse to saue, then spill,
Him selfe to saue: but he there slew him at the skreene.
